content.webTitle: Else Fitzgerald wins 2019 Richell prize for short stories that 'feel like a revelation'

fields.headline: Else Fitzgerald wins 2019 Richell prize for short stories that 'feel like a revelation'
fields.bodyText: When writer Else Fitzgerald was a kid, drought sent her family bankrupt. They owned a nursery in regional Victoria. “We lived our lives by the weather,” Fitzgerald said. “So I have this fascination with how people deal with the challenges of climate change.” Now, the 33-year-old has won this year’s $10,000 Richell prize for emerging writers for Nearly Curtains, a collection of stories drawing on that fascination. Nearly Curtains explores a future ravaged by climate crisis and the divergent responses to it – from couples questioning whether or not they ought to have children, to the roles technologies such as genetic manipulation may play in how humanity adapts to the changing world. The Richell prize, supported by Hachette Australia, Guardian Australia and the Emerging Writers’ festival, was established in 2015 and is open to emerging writers of both fiction and narrative non-fiction. The judging panel – including Robert Watkins, the head of literary at Hachette Australia; authors Hannah Richell and Sarah Schmidt; and Steve Sines, bookseller at Potts Point Bookshop – hailed Nearly Curtains as “a firework show of bursting ideas”. “The strength of Nearly Curtains is more than its beautiful prose, characterisation and concept: here is an emerging writer who has captured the heart of humanity in crisis with such insight that it feels like a revelation,” the judges’ report said. “At the moment I don’t know how I could be writing about anything else,” Fitzgerald told Guardian Australia. “[Climate crisis] feels really big and urgent and you can’t ignore it.” Sign up to receive the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning Fitzgerald said working through her own emotional responses to the climate crisis – from “sheer terror” at worst, to trying to think through how to cope – was a constant preoccupation. The question about whether or not to have children is “one of those things I’ve certainly had to wrestle with”, she said – a question the characters in one of her stories, Fertile Ground, also grapple with. “For our generation there is a particular set of challenges. I don’t know that that’s necessarily unique to us. Our parents and the generations before them have had their own things to surmount, whether that’s nuclear crisis or the second world war.” Fitzgerald’s manuscript was chosen from 704 entries, whittled down to a shortlist of six. Hachette has published six books by winning or shortlisted writers since the prize first opened in 2015. “The timing is amazing for me because I’ve just come off the back of 18 months of working all of these different jobs, sometimes five or six at a time,” Fitzgerald said. “Because I’ve had such an erratic schedule, it’s been challenging to find time to really get into the writing project. Winning something like the Richell prize just means that I will have a bit of time to focus on finishing off this manuscript.” Along with the money, the prize also includes a 12-month mentorship with publishing house Hachette Australia. Fitzgerald, who previously worked for the Emerging Writers festival, was effusive about the difference opportunities like the prize made for emerging writers. “The money is one thing but the guidance and support that you get for a year – I can’t even begin to explain how valuable and special that is,” she said.
